sect1.title: CASE 65
sect1.para: A 21-year-old female was referred to a dermatologist by her primary care physician for evaluation of bilateral leg lesions like those depicted in Fig. 65.1. The lesions first appeared 4 months ago, and they came and went, leaving a red mark that persisted for about a month. The lesions did not itch, burn, or bleed. She denied fever and had had no other symptoms. No one else in her family had similar lesions.

listitem.para: 1. What are the common pathogens that cause skin and soft tissue infections (SSTIs)?

sect1.para: Upon physical examination, the lesions were noted to be erythematous to violaceous and firm with no purulent drainage. The lesions were isolated to her lower legs, and there were eight lesions in various stages of development. The patient refused a biopsy and preferred empiric treatment for what was presumed to be arthropod bites. She returned to the dermatologist 6 weeks later because the lesions had become considerably larger. During this visit, she denied owning an aquarium but recalled having a pedicure 2 weeks before the onset of lesions. An 8-mm punch biopsy was obtained and sent for histopathologic and microbiologic analysis. The Gram stain of the biopsy is shown in Fig. 65.2.

listitem.para: 2. How does the Gram stain result help narrow the list of organisms that might be the cause of her infection? What additional stains or tests are needed?

sect1.para: The punch biopsy was cultured for routine bacteria, mycobacteria, and fungi. An organism grew aerobically after 5 days of incubation from both bacterial and mycobacterial cultures.Figure 65.3 shows the organism after subculture to Middlebrook 7H11 agar. A Kinyoun stain was performed from the colonies, which is shown in Fig. 65.4.

listitem.para: 3. To what group does this organism belong? Briefly describe the epidemiology of this group of organisms. What is the significance of the patient’s having received a pedicure but not having an aquarium?
4. Several species make up this group of organisms. Does knowing the species help inform therapeutic choices?
5. What other types of infections does this organism cause?

6. Because the organism that caused the patient’s infection is an environmental organism, it can be difficult to distinguish colonization from infection, particularly for pulmonary disease. What guidelines exist to aid in this interpretation?

sect1.para: 1. The most common causes of SSTIs are Staphylococcus aureus and Streptococcus pyogenes, which can cause a wide spectrum of clinical presentations from uncomplicated folliculitis, furunculosis, and cellulitis to necrotizing infections (1). Though less common, Clostridium spp. (namely, C. perfringens and C. septicum) can also cause SSTIs, including necrotizing infections. If the patient had a history of an animal bite or an animal licking her wounds, organisms such as Pasteurella spp. and Capnocytophaga spp. would need to be considered. Patients who have exposure to fresh, brackish, or salt water can have SSTIs due to Vibrio vulnificus, Aeromonas hydrophila, or Mycobacterium marinum. Her clinical course was chronic in nature, as these lesions had been present and progressing for weeks to months. Except for M. marinum, all the organisms listed above would have caused more rapidly progressing infections. Her chronic infection was most likely due to an aerobic actinomycete (e. g.,Nocardia), nontuberculous Mycobacterium, or fungus.

2. The Gram stain shows poorly staining, or beaded, Gram-positive bacilli. Therefore, a fungal infection can be ruled out. The poor staining usually indicates an organism that has higher mycolic acid content in the cell wall, which is consistent with mycobacteria. Nocardia spp. can also have a similar Gram stain, so culture is needed for definitive identification. An acid-fast stain, like Kinyoun, can be performed to differentiate between mycobacteria (positive, pink) and Nocardia (negative, blue). If the Kinyoun is negative, a modified Kinyoun could be performed to differentiate between Nocardia (positive) and other aerobic actinomycetes, like Streptomyces (negative).

3. Both mycobacteria and Nocardia spp. can be cultured from mycobacterial cultures, but the waxy appearance of colonies in Fig. 65.3 is consistent with mycobacteria. Nocardia spp. typically have a very white, chalky appearance. Both may also grow from routine bacterial cultures, depending on the specimen’s organism burden and how long the cultures are held. The positive Kinyoun stain confirms that this was a Mycobacterium species. Nontuberculous mycobacteria can be separated into two large groups: slowly growing mycobacteria and rapidly growing mycobacteria (RGM). RGM generally grow within 7 days; therefore, this patient’s infection was likely due to RGM.

There are ≥75 species of RGM, which represent ~50% of all mycobacterial species(2). RGM are ubiquitous environmental organisms typically found in municipal tap water. RGM have also been isolated from 30 to 78% of U. S. soil samples. Many species can survive in hostile environments, including increased temperatures (45°C). RGM form biofilms and have readily been recovered from pipes supplying water to dialysis centers and hospitals, which have led to local outbreaks. Health care-associated outbreaks have been linked to tap water, ice machines, and water-based solutions, as well as heater-cooler devices (3, 4). In addition, pseudo-outbreaks have been described due to contaminated bronchoscopes and endoscopes causing positive cultures that were not due to true clinical infections (5).

During the time period when this patient presented with furunculosis, several other local cases of bilateral lower extremity furunculosis were confirmed to be due to RGM(6). All patients had a history of getting pedicures, but at different nail salons; thus, eliciting the history of pedicures was important in narrowing her differential diagnosis. The species of RGM isolated from the cases were not identical, and further investigation found 40 local pedicure-associated RGM infections over a 4-year period. Environmental sampling demonstrated that multiple species of RGM could be recovered from tap water, footbath water, and pipe biofilms from both case and control nail salons. Therefore, it appears that RGM are endemic in this setting and additional factors, such as host susceptibility, play a role in the development of infection. It is known that recent skin trauma such as shaving is a predisposing factor.

Because infections due to M. marinum can present similarly, the patient was asked if she had an aquarium. M. marinum is found in fresh- and salt water, and infections caused by it are usually associated with aquarium or fish exposure. However, these infections more commonly occur on the hands and arms than the lower extremities. M. marinum is a slowly growing nontuberculous mycobacterial species.

4. The most common species of RGM associated with human infections are Mycobacterium abscessus complex, Mycobacterium chelonae, and Mycobacterium fortuitum. Historically, these species have been difficult to identify in the laboratory, but the use of sequencing and mass spectrometry has greatly improved the accuracy of species-level identification. Species-level identification can be helpful in predicting certain antimicrobial susceptibility patterns (7). For example, M. fortuitum is usually susceptible to trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole and fluoroquinolones, whereas M. abscessus complex and M. chelonae are often resistant to both. Macrolide resistance is of concern since this antimicrobial is often used empirically, and resistance can be inducible. With M. abscessus complex, subspecies-level identification is important for predicting clinical response to macrolide therapy (8). Most M. abscessus subsp. abscessus and M. abscessus subsp. bolletii have an inducible erm(41) gene (encoding a ribosomal methylase), whereas M. abscessus subsp. massiliense does not. Extending the incubation time for susceptibility tests to 14 days is needed to detect inducible macrolide resistance, so there is often a delay in final susceptibility results. Molecular analysis of the erm(41) gene may be used to provide more rapid results for clarithromycin susceptibility (9). Although subspecies identification can predict the utility of macrolide therapy, this level of identification is challenging. Most laboratories report these organisms as “M. abscessus complex” with no further differentiation, which necessitates antimicrobial susceptibility testing. While species- and subspecies-level identification can help guide empiric therapeutic choices, susceptibility testing should still be performed since many of these infections get treated with combination therapy for 6 months to 1 year. This patient’s isolate was identified as M. abscessus subsp. massiliense, which was confirmed to be susceptible to clarithromycin as predicted by its identification. A recent study described a new erm gene, erm(55), associated with inducible clindamycin resistance in M. chelonae (10). It was also found in isolates of Mycobacterium iranicum and Mycobacterium obuense and was found chromosomally and on a plasmid. This finding raises a concern for more widespread, previously unrecognized, inducible clindamycin resistance in RGM.

5. RGM have been associated with a wide variety of infections, with pulmonary infections and cutaneous infections being the most common (2). Cosmetic procedures, often associated with medical tourism, have been associated with postprocedural RGM infections (11). RGM can also cause line-related sepsis (e. g., central line, peripherally inserted central catheter), particularly in immunocompromised patients. RGM readily form biofilms on indwelling catheters, creating a nidus for continued infection until the catheter is removed.M. abscessus complex is associated with chronic pulmonary infections, particularly in patients with cystic fibrosis, as well as posttraumatic and surgical wound infections. It has also been associated with chronic otitis media following tympanostomy. M. chelonae can cause posttraumatic wound infections and posttraumatic or postsurgical corneal infections (12). There has been a particular association of RGM infections with LASIK procedures and punctal plugs used for dry eye syndrome. Like other RGM, M. fortuitum can be recovered from cases of posttraumatic and surgical wound infections but has been more frequently recovered following breast and cardiac surgeries. In addition to causing sporadic infections as described above, RGM have been responsible for several outbreaks. Tattooing, plastic surgery, and acupuncture are some procedures associated with repeated outbreaks.

6. The American Thoracic Society and the Infectious Diseases Society of America have published guidelines to assist with the diagnosis of nontuberculous mycobacterial disease (13). The clinical criteria to establish the diagnosis of lung disease due to nontuberculous mycobacteria, including RGM, are (i) pulmonary symptoms or systemic symptoms, nodular or cavitary opacities on chest radiograph, or a high-resolution computed tomography scan showing multifocal bronchiectasis with multiple small nodules; and (ii) appropriate exclusion of other diagnoses. Microbiologic criteria can also be assessed, particularly when a patient does not have clear disease based on the clinical criteria above. One of the following microbiologic criteria should be met to consider lung disease attributable to RGM (and other nontuberculous mycobacteria): (i) positive cultures from ≥2 sputa, (ii) positive culture from ≥1 bronchial wash or lavage, or (iii) lung biopsy with histopathologic features consistent with mycobacterial infection (e. g., granulomatous inflammation or the presence of acid-fast bacilli in tissue) and a positive culture from at least one pulmonary specimen. If these criteria are not met in a person suspected of having nontuberculous mycobacterial lung disease, continued clinical and microbiologic monitoring may be needed to establish a diagnosis.

listitem.para: The etiology of chronic SSTIs in an immunocompetent patient varies based on environmental exposure, but could include Nocardia, nontuberculous Mycobacterium spp. (rapidly growing mycobacteria and M. marinum), and fungi.
Mycobacteria are often faintly staining, or beaded, by Gram stain. They are Kinyoun positive, which helps different them from Nocardia and other aerobic actinomycetes.

RGM may cause chronic skin lesions in individuals with exposure to nail salons (pedicures), cosmetic procedures associated with medical tourism, and environmental or surgical trauma. RGM also cause pulmonary infections in patients with cystic fibrosis or other chronic lung diseases and are associated with line-related sepsis in immunocompromised patients.

Species-level identification of RGM and subspecies-level identification of Mycobacterium abscessus complex are important for informing empiric antibiotics while antimicrobial susceptibility testing is being performed.
Extending the incubation time for antimicrobial susceptibility tests to 14 days or molecular analysis of theerm(41) gene is needed to detect inducible macrolide resistance in M. abscessus complex.

Since RGM are both environmental organisms and potential pathogens, guidelines exist to help with clinical diagnosis. The criteria for establishing a diagnosis of lung disease due to nontuberculous mycobacteria rely on symptoms, radiology results, and microbiology results.
